title-group.article-title: Feedback/feedforward modeling and control of electroosmotic flow in a T-shape microchannel

abstract.p: Electroosmotic effect is usually utilized to generate the flow field in microfluidic systems. In many of these microdevices, an accurate control over the output flow rate of the microfluidic part is necessary for the successful operation of the whole system. In this study, a combined feedback/feedforward strategy is proposed to control the output flow rate in a micro-T-junction. First, finite element model of the electroosmotic flow in the T-junction is generated; second, using the adaptive neural fuzzy inference system, the finite element model forms a basis for generating training data for building an inverse model of the flow in the micro-T-junction. This inverse model serves as a controller in the feedforward part of the system. Then, in order to make the controller robust against disturbances and uncertainties such as dimensional tolerances, a Mamdani-type fuzzy logic controller is incorporated in the feedback part of the controller. Finally, simulation results are presented in order to proof the performance of the designed controller.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Electrokinetic phenomena are a group of different effects that become important in micron and submicron dimensions.1 Electrokinetic phenomena were first discovered by Ruess in 1806; however, it took until 1994 when Probstein divided linear electrokinetic phenomena into four categories, namely electroosmosis, electrophoresis, streaming potential, and sedimentation potential. Electroosmotic flow (which is the result of the electroosmosis effect) is the motion of liquid, induced by an applied potential across capillary tubes or microchannels. The electroosmotic flow has many advantages compared to its counterparts such as being vibration free, compact, and having flat-form velocity profile. The electroosmotic flow in microfluidic devices has extensively been studied during the past decade for several applications such as mixing, DNA analysis, and delivery of drugs, biological molecules, and chemical samples.2–6

The microfluidic systems usually utilize electroosmotic pumps to generate flow field in their microchannels. This pump is so compact and vibration-free. These lab-on-a-chip designs usually involve different parts such as electrodes, biological and chemical detection units, and flow control elements which should be coordinated in a way that the device can precisely perform. However, the performance of these systems is usually prone to different disturbances such as imperfections in the form of manufacturing dimensional errors. To insure the best performance of these devices, in this study, we propose utilizing electroosmotic flow with closed-loop control system. To cope with the sources of inaccuracy, we implement the feedback control concept which has the potential to compensate for those unknown sources of error and uncertainty.

Literature review shows that the studies in the field of the control of the electroosmotic flow in the microchannels can mainly be grouped into two categories. The first set includes those studies which only apply feedforward (open-loop) control concept to the control of the electroosmotic flow. For example, Dutta et al.7 developed numerical models for describing fluid flow in complex microgeometries such as cross-flow junctions and Y-split channels. By utilizing these numerical models, they could predict the flow rate in branches of such microgeometries. Also, Hahm8 modified locally applied electric fields and zeta potential patterned groove surfaces to control fluid and species transport in grooved microchannels. The second group of studies includes those which proposed practical devices in order to control electroosmotic flow in microchannels.9–11 As an example, Oroszi et al.12 employed light as a means of the actuator to control the electroosmotic flow. They could locally change the electric field intensity by illuminating a photoconductive wall and, as a result, the electroosmotic driving force could be controlled. Therefore, to the best of our knowledge, feedback control concept has not yet been employed in order to control the electroosmotic flow in microchannels.

Microfluidic systems usually contain microchannel networks with different kinds of junctions such as cross-flows, Y-splits, and T-junctions. In this study, the flow control of the T-junction is investigated; however, the proposed methodology can be easily extended to the other types of junctions. Since the governing equations of the electroosmotic flow in microchannels are nonlinear partial differential equations, the conventional model-based control strategies may not be easily utilized. Therefore, we incorporate intelligent control strategies in combination with the closed-loop control concept to accurately regulate the electroosmotic flow rate in the T-junction of the microchannels. To implement the proposed controller, we will incorporate the feedback/feedforward control strategy. In the feedforward and the feedback parts of the controller, an inverse model of the system based on the adaptive neural fuzzy inference system (ANFIS) and the Mamdani-type fuzzy logic (FL) controller are utilized, respectively, in order to increase the robustness of the controller against model uncertainties and disturbances.

In order to design the proposed controller, the following steps are performed. First, finite element method (FEM) is utilized in order to obtain a numerical model of the micro-T-junction; next, this model generates the required training data for ANFIS to acquire the inverse model of the electroosmotic flow in the T-junction. This inverse model serves as a controller in the feedforward part of the system. However, since dimensional errors in manufacturing of microfluidic devices are inevitable; there is always an error between the desired flow rate and the actual one produced in the feedforward part. To reduce this error, a feedback part based on the Mamdani-type FL controller is added to the system. Finally, the performance of the proposed controller will be numerically investigated.

sec.title: Theory and mathematical modeling
sec.p: This section presents a brief review of channel categories (based on their dimensions), the electroosmotic flow and its governing equations. Further information on these topics can be found in the studies of Li5 and Kandlikar et al.13

sec.p:
Channels are usually characterized on the basis of their smallest dimension, D; following categories can be defined for the channels (Table 1).13 Table 1.

sec.title: Electroosmotic flow
sec.p:
The nature of the electroosmotic flow is demonstrated in Figure 1. Electroosmosis is the motion of ionized liquid relative to the stationary charged surfaces by an applied external electric field.14 Electroosmotic phenomenon is present due to the electric double layer effect (EDL), which is formed as a result of the interaction of ionized solution with static charges on dielectric surfaces. The extent of the EDL can be approximately predicted by the Debye length, which is defined as the distance from the wall, where the electrokinetic potential energy is equal to the thermal energy. Figure 1.
Schematic of the electroosmotic flow in a planar channel with the finite EDL.

When the ionic liquid comes into contact with most non-conductive materials such as glass and silicon capillary walls, the small immobile charges appear on the wall surfaces (Figure 1). Ionization, absorption, and dissociation of the ions in the capillary material lead to the charge build up which is counteracted by charges being drawn out of the solution toward the interface. The charges on the solution side of the interface, unlike that on the capillary surface, are mobile and move parallel to the applied electric field. The thin layer of mobile charges drags the neutral bulk of the solution along the channel in a plug-like manner due to viscous forces.14

In most lab-on-a-chip applications, electroosmotic flow is preferred over the pressure driven flow. One reason for this is the plug-like velocity profile of the electroosmotic flow. This means that fluid samples can be transported without dispersion caused by flow shear. Pumping a liquid through a small microchannel usually requires applying extremely large p pressure gradient. This is often impossible because of the limitations of the size and the mechanical strength of the microfluidic devices. The electroosmotic flow can generate the required flow rate even in extremely small microchannels without any applied pressure difference across the channel. Additionally, using the electroosmotic flow to transport liquids in complex microchannel networks does not require external mechanical pumps; it can be easily accomplished by controlling the electrical fields via electrodes. Although high voltages are often required in the electroosmotic flow, the required electrical power is remarkably small due to particularly low current involved; therefore, it is safe.

Direct and indirect methods have been proposed to measure the electroosmotic velocity in the microchannels. Direct method is based on the flow visualization. In this method, the solution is seeded with caged fluorescent dyes. The fluorescent microscope is exploited for displacement of the dyes at the interval time of Δt. Thus, the averaged (observed) velocity of the dyes can be calculated as u¯ob=Δx/Δt; this observed velocity is the summation of the averaged electroosmotic velocity (u¯) and the averaged electrophoretic velocity of the particle (u¯ep). Simple calculation is then utilized to find the averaged electroosmotic velocity in the microchannels (u¯=u¯ob-u¯ep). The averaged electrophoretic velocity of the particle is function of electrical and fluid characteristics of the system: u¯ep=2ɛɛ0ςsEz/3μ. Here, ε and ε0 are the relative and absolute permeability, respectively, ςs the zeta-potential, μ the fluid viscosity, and Ez the externally applied electric field. It is shown that the presence of the dyes has negligible effects on the electroosmotic flow in the microchannels.

Indirect approach is based on the measurement of the electrical current in the microchannels; inlet and outlet reservoirs need to have different ionic concentrations. The electroosmotic flow field changes the ionic concentration and consequently electrical current in the microchannels. The electroosmotic velocity can then be calculated based on the measurement of the electrical current.15 Both direct and indirect methods have their own advantages and disadvantages. However, the accuracy and rapidness of the both methods have been experimentally approved.15 Thus, any time delays in the performance of the sensors will be ignored in this study.

sec.title: Governing equations
sec.p: The flow field of the electroosmotic flow can be obtained by solving the following set of partial differential equations subjected to proper boundary conditions. For thin electric double layer, Helmholtz–Smoluchowski slip velocity may be utilized to find the electroosmotic velocity in microchannels14 (1)∇→·u→=0 (2)ρ∂u→∂t+ρu→·∇u→=-∇p+μ∇2u→ (3)uhs=-ςɛɛ0Exμ (4)∇→·u→=0 (5)∇2φ=0 (6)E→=-∇φ (7)φ=φi (8)n→·E→=0

Equations (1) and (2) are the continuity and the Navier–Stokes equations, respectively. The Helmholtz–Smoluchowski slip velocity is applied at the walls of the microchannels to consider the influences of the electroosmosis on the flow field (equation (3)). Ends of the microchannels are assumed as an open boundary (equation (4)). This type of boundary condition is usually utilized when the channel is opened to the large reservoir; at this type of boundary, flow may either enter to or exit from the channel. The Laplace equation (equation (5)) is utilized to find the electric potential due to the applied external electric field in the channels; applied external electric field is the gradient of this electric potential (equation (6)). Constant electric potential (equation (7)) is considered at the ends of the microchannels where the electrodes are located. The walls of the microchannels are assumed to be electrically insulated (equation (8)).

In the above equations, ∇ is the Nabla operator, u→ and p the velocity vector and pressure, correspondingly, ϕ and E→ the electric potential and electric field, respectively, and ς the zeta potential that is the electric potential at the walls of the channels and due to the electric double layer. The constants include permittivity (ε0εr), medium density (ρ), and fluid viscosity (μ).

sec.title: System modeling
sec.p:
In this study, incompressible flow of Newtonian fluid with slip-velocity boundary condition in planar microchannels is assumed and control of the electroosmotic flow in a micro-T-junction is investigated. Figure 2 shows the schematic diagram of the assumed micro-T-junction. The intention of the proposed control system is to regulate the flow rate in OB-branch of the T-junction by manipulation of the voltage at the end of OC-branch (ϕc). It should be noted that the voltages at the ends of OA- and OB-branches and also ζ-potential on the walls of the T-junction are kept constant. The applied voltages at the ends of these branches (OA and OB) have different values. The dimensions and flow parameters of the electroosmotic flow in this microgeometry are presented in Table 2. Also, in order to simulate the flow in the T-junction, a commercial finite element software package (COMSOL Multiphysics 3.5a) is used. Figure 2.

sec.title: Controller design
sec.p:
It is known that feedforward control is best deployed in control systems design applications where the process or controlled variable behavior is well understood. A well-understood process is one in which the first principal equations describing the process are known for the given application, and are correctly applied to adequately describe the process. On the other hand, feedback control is typically used when the accuracy provided by feedforward controls is not adequate to meet the application performance specifications. Here, using the feedback control seems to be beneficial because of some sources of inaccuracy in the model of this study. The zeta potential is dependent on the pH value and bulk ionic concentration. Therefore, Helmholtz–Smoluchowski velocity (equation (3)) may not be fixed and causes some uncertainties in the system.5 Inaccuracies are also inevitable in fabrication of microfluidic devices. For example, fabrication systems may not be completely horizontal that make flow movement during the baking of the microchips; it may cause some inaccuracy in the pre-defined dimensions of the system. Presence of the dusts and debris changes the cross-sectional area of the microchannels. Thus, in this study, feedback–feedforward controller is considered to boast the accuracy of the system. Feedforward controller is the inverse model of the plant. The Mamdani-type Fuzzy controller is used in the feedback part of the system as a robust technique to enhance the performance of the system. Figure 3 illustrates the structure of the proposed feedback/feedforward controller. In the following, design procedures for both feedforward and feedback parts of the system are presented. Figure 3.
Structure of the proposed feedback/feedforward controller.

sec.title: Inverse model of the T-junction
sec.p: Like every other control problem, the plant under consideration should be modeled as accurately as possible. As it was mentioned in the previous section, the flow field in the microchannels is governed by the set of partial differential equations; therefore, obtaining an inverse mathematical model for the flow in the microchannels can be quite challenging. The inverse model takes desired flow rate of the branch OB as an input to determine the required applied voltage at point C (ϕc). In this study, we have exploited the modeling capabilities of the ANFIS in order to acquire the inverse model of the flow in the T-junction; this model should relate applied voltage at point C to the flow rate of branch OB. ANFIS has combined the advantages of artificial neural networks with FL which has resulted in a powerful method in modeling complex nonlinear systems and in the literature, different applications can be found in the areas like function approximation, fault detection, medical diagnosis, and control. Unlike conventional fuzzy inference systems (FIS), ANFIS modeling technique does not depend on the opinion of an expert who is familiar with the plant and it only requires an input–output data set either from the mathematical model or actual prototype of the plant. In this study, ANFIS architecture is used to model a dynamic system, which is taken as a black box, i.e. described by its observed responses to the introduced inputs. In the sequel, the ANFIS method will be briefly explained.

sec.title: ANFIS: Adaptive network-based fuzzy inference system
sec.p: The structure of ANFIS has five layers and it uses Takagi–Sugeno–Kang (TSK) fuzzy inference model to be the learning algorithm.16 Consider structure of FIS with two inputs, x and y, and one output z. The typical fuzzy IF-THEN rule for the TSK fuzzy system becomes Rulei:If(xisAi)and(yisBi),thenfi=pix+qiy+ri

Here, x and y inputs constitute the premise variables of the fuzzy rules, Ai and Bi the premise parameters, and pi, qi, and ri the consequence parameters. Using the fi functions, which are combinations of consequent parameters, and the weight values of wi, the overall output function f for this TS model is expressed as (consider i = 1, 2) (9)f=w1f1+w2f2w1+w2=w¯1f1+w¯2f2

The corresponding ANFIS model for TS fuzzy structure is given in Figure 4. As it is seen from this figure, ANFIS has five layers and functions of these layers can be explained briefly as below.
Layer 1: In this layer where the fuzzification process takes place, every node is adaptive. Outputs of this layer form the membership values of the premise part.
Layer 2: In contrast to Layer 1 the nodes in this layer are fixed. Each node output represents a firing strength of a rule.
Layer 3: In this layer where the normalization process is performed, the nodes are fixed as they are in Layer 2. The ratio of the ith rule’s firing strength to the sum of all rules firing strengths is calculated for the corresponding node.
Layer 4: Since the nodes in this layer operate as a function block, whose variables are the input values, they are adaptive. Consequently, the output of this layer forms TSK outputs and hence is referred as the consequent part.
Layer 5: This is the summation layer, which consists of a single fixed node. It sums up all the incoming signals and produces the output.
Figure 4.
ANFIS model for TS fuzzy structure.

sec.title: Feedback controller
sec.p: As it was mentioned earlier, feedback part is added to the system to increase the robustness of the system against model uncertainties and disturbances; therefore, in feedback loop, we have exploited a robust controller namely, FL controller. In the following, the design procedure for the Mamdani-type FL controller is briefly presented.

sec.title: Fuzzy controller
sec.p: The concepts of fuzzy set theory, fuzzy IF-THEN rules, and fuzzy reasoning are the basis of the framework called FIS. An FIS is a knowledge-based system that converts linguistic variables into its knowledge base using fuzzy rules and membership functions. FISs are also known as fuzzy rule-based systems, fuzzy models, fuzzy associative memories (FAM), or fuzzy controllers when used as controllers.17

Basically, an FIS is composed of five functional blocks (Figure 5).

NL, NS, Z, PS, and PL are the linguistic variables to describe the inputs and outputs of the fuzzy system.

sec.title: Simulations and results
sec.p:
In order to investigate the performance of the designed controller, system responses for regulation of flow rate to a desired value are numerically simulated. Also, to examine the robustness of the controller, a disturbance in the form of dimensional inaccuracy in manufacturing of the microchannel (about 2% increase in width of the channel) is introduced in the finite element model of the T-junction. Figure 9 illustrates error (e), flow rate in OB-branch (QOB), and applied voltage at the end of OC-branch (VOC). As it can be seen from this figure, after the first iteration in time, the output flow rate is 6.497E−8 (m3/s); however, the desired flow rate is 6.350E−8 (m3/s) (e = 2.32%). Therefore, in order to reduce this error, the feedback part which operates based on Mamdani-type fuzzy control has been added to the system. Clearly, it can be seen form Figure 9 that after each iteration in the time, the error becomes smaller and the output flow rate converges to the desired value. The transient response of the electroosmotic flow in microchannels is in the order of microsecond; thus, in this study, each time step is assumed to be 1 µs. Figure 9.
Simulation results: (a) error associated with the flow rate in OB-branch, (b) flow rate of the OB-branch, and (c) applied voltage at the end of branch OC.

For the obtained controlled value of the applied electric potential at point C (φc=255V), Figure 10 shows the electric potential and the velocity field in the system. The typical value of the external electric field in the microfluidic systems is in the range 1-100V/mm.14 Larger applied voltages may cause some instability in the system. In this study, the averaged electric field is ≈ 10 V/mm that is sufficiently lower than the typical maximum value of the microfluidic systems. Figure 10(b) shows the velocity field of the system. It can be seen that the velocity vectors have approximately the same magnitude at the cross-section of the channels that represent the plug-like nature of the velocity profile of the electroosmotic flow field in microchannels. Figure 10.
(a) Electric potential and (b) velocity field for the controlled parameters of the system (φc=255V).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this article, the feasibility of the use of neural network and fuzzy modeling capabilities in controlling and modeling of microfluidic systems was investigated. In order to explore this concept, the simulation power of COMSOL Multiphysics 3.5a was utilized; which on one hand could numerically simulate flow in microchannels and on the other hand could be linked to Matlab’s fuzzy and neural network toolboxes. In this study, a combined feedback/feedforward strategy was exploited in order to control the output flow rate in a micro-T-junction. First, finite element model of the electroosmotic flow in the T-junction was generated, and then based on this model, training data were generated for building an inverse model of the flow in the T-junction based on ANFIS. This inverse model served as the controller in the feedforward part of the system. Also, in order to make the controller robust against disturbances and uncertainties such as dimensional tolerances, a Mamdani-type FL controller was incorporated in the feedback part of the controller. Finally, simulation results showed that adding the feedback controller to the feedforward part of the controller not only has considerably reduced the value of the error but also has made the overall controller robust against the uncertainties and disturbances.

Finally, it should be noted that there are some limitations in the applied electric field of the system. The typical range of external electric field in microchannels is 1-100V/mm.14 There are some disadvantages associated with the electric field beyond this range such as Joule heating, generating of electric pulse, and bubble generation. It causes some constraints to a total throughput flow.
